question: 1 (i)
sols_html:
First, we remove the improper integral to get

\(\int_{e}^{\infty}\frac{1}{x(\ln x)^{2}} \, dx = \lim_{b \to \infty} \int_{e}^{b}\frac{1}{x(\ln x)^{2}}\).

Then we proceed by substitution. Let \(u = \ln x\) so that \(du = \tfrac{1}{x} dx\). The endpoints become \(u(e) = \ln e = 1\) and \(u(b) = \ln b\). Hence, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{e}^{\infty}\frac{1}{x(\ln x)^{2}} \, dx &= \lim_{b \to \infty} \int_{e}^{b}\frac{1}{x(\ln x)^{2}}\, dx\\ &= \lim_{b \to \infty} \int_{1}^{\ln b}\frac{1}{(u)^{2}}\,du \\ &= \lim_{b \to \infty} -u^{-1}|_{1}^{\ln b} \\ &= \lim_{b \to \infty} -\frac{1}{\ln b} + \frac{1}{1}\\ &= 1\end{aligned}\]

completing the question.

$du = \tfrac{1}{x} dx$. The endpoints become $u(e) = \ln e = 1$ and

\begin{align*}

&= \lim_{b \to \infty} -u^{-1}|_{1}^{\ln b} \\

&= 1
\end{align*}

completing the question.
